ENGINEERING LECTURES

Public lectures on engineering
practice have been arranged by the
Engineering School to take the
place of the J. E. Aldred series,
which has been discontinued this
year .
The new course will be similar
in purpose anti method to the Aldred lectures, although only four addresses will be given. The lectures
are designed principally to supplement the engineering course for
undergraduate students.
The addresses, which will be held
at 4.15 o'clock in the C. E. Hall,
are as follows:
March 8—"Construction of the
Catskill water supply for the City
of New York," by J. Waldo Smith,

chief engineer of the Board of Water Supply, New York City.
March 15-,—"Some Results of the
War on Engineering Research," by
C. E. Skinner, manager of the research department of the Westinghouse Electric Company, East Pittsburgh, Pa.
March 22—"Engineering Problems Involving Atmospheric Pressure," by W. H. Carrier, president
of the Carrier Engineering Corporation, Newark, N. J.
March 29 — "Magnesium, Its
Manufacture and Use," by 1.V. G.
Harvey, vice-president and superintendent of the American Magnesium Corporation, Niagara Falls,
N.Y.

STUDENT COUNCIL

A BOOST, SENIORS
The Seniors also come in for their mead of praise. Their dance
Is a wonderful success. The decorations played no small part in their
triumph, although good music and refreshments, and attractive girls,

their share.

and ability the C. E. Hall was changed into a veritable art gallery.

at the Vagabond Theatre.

SENIORS

All class dues must be paid by
March 1, 1922. The treasurer will
be at the Hullabaloo office in the
Earn, daily, from February 23 to
March 1, inclusive, from 11:30 A.
M. to 1 :30 P. M.
SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB MEETING

There will be a meeting of the
Social Science Club today at 2:30,
in Room 113, Gilman Hall. A discussion on "Nationalism vs. Internationalism" will be held.

BOB SKINNER ELECTED VICEPRESIDENT OF FRESHMAN
CLASS

The first meeting of the Freshman Class was held Tuesday, at
12:30, in the auditorium of the
Civil Engineering Building. After
calling the meeting to order, President Page O'Connor announced
that plans for the banquet were being arranged. After this a vote was
taken to see how many of the members of the class desired pins, but,
as there were so very many who
didn't want them, it was decided
"to let the matter slide until next
year." Treasurer "Bill" Norris
then announced that a plan had
b(:.en devised for collecting the dues
"Toots" Darley, of the Engineering School, and Gedige Hess, of
the Academic Department, are to
act as his assistants and are to keep
after the Freshmen until the dues
are paid.
President O'Connor took the
chair again and announced that
new officers would have to be elected to take the places of Spinney,
the vice-president, and Westerman,
the sergeant-at-arms, who had been
dropped from the University. Magill, Asendorf, "Bob" Skinner and
"Ed" Panneti were nominated for
vice-president. Post, Young and
Rome were nominated. to fill the position of "bouncer." Skinner was
elected vice-president. Post was
elected to the other office.

THE GAYEST EVER HELD
AT HOPKINS
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Decorations Overshadow Anything of
the Kind Ever Attempted. Spirit
of Jazz Unconfined.

Surrounded by the most futuristic, impressionistic, cubistic, tapestries which ever adorned an otherwise solemn hall, the Class of
1922 unlimbered their studently
limbs and gave themselves over to
joy unconfined and swayed themselves to thewierd strains of Seidenham's sorrow-killing orchestra of
seven pieces.
With all thoughts of unhappy
exams behind them and caring little for the future, seventy-five
couples threw their whole energies
into the delightful pastime sponsored by the god Terpsichore; caring little for the harmful news-articles daily published by minds long
since exhausted of other moneygetting material.
With the "King and Queen of
Jazz" beaming upon their disciples,
the dance went on from 9:30 P. M.
until nearly 2 A. M., 'Wednesday
morning.
The decorations were by far the
most impressive ever used at such
an affair. The personal ones Dean
Latane, Drs. Wood, French and
Mitchell rivalled those of jazzier
subjects, such as the "Cave-man's
Petting Party," "The Leg of Nations," "Mrs. Salome," the "First
Shimmy," etc.
The patrons and patronesses
were: Dr. Frank J. Goodnow, Dean
and Mrs. John B. Whitehead, Professor and Mrs. Knight Dunlap,
Mr. and Mrs. Robertson Griswold,
Dr. and Mrs. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Professor and Mrs. J. H. Gregory, Dr. and Mrs. Luther M. Parsons, Dr. and Mrs. Ray Van Orman and Mrs. Christopher Johnson.

ADVERTISE HOPKINS!

Editor of NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir: In order to help our
university by advertising it and
keeping its name before the public,
locally at least, I suggest that every
motor vehicle operated by any person connected in any capacity with
the university carry a suitable and
inexpensive Hopkins banner, pennant or emblem.
The difficulty of carrying out
such an idea as this is that someone must start it and put it into the
form of a custom by making it
popular. With this in mind, our
Motorcycle Club is ready to take
the lead and start the practice of
carrying a Hopkins banner, pennant or emblem on its machines.
Respectfully yours,
EDWARD F. BUCHNER, JR.

American universities which have
completed athletic stadiums within
the decade, or have provided for
their construction, include California, Ohio State, Yale, Illinois,
Baltimore. Charles and Fayette
Stanford, Chicago, Washington,
Princeton, Kansas, Pittsburgh and
the City College of New York. Of
these, Yale's stadium cost $400,000
and seats 70,000; Washington spent
$600,000 and can seat 60,000; California is spending $900,000 to seat
60,000; Illinois is planning a combined stadium and amphitheater to
cost $2,500,000, and Ohio State
raised $1,250,000. No 'stadium yet
completed has been large enough
to meet the immediate demand for
seats. These facts, together with

ENGINEERING LECTURES

Public lectures on engineering
practice have been arranged by the
Engineering School to take the
place of the J. E. Aldred series,
which has been discontinued this
year .
The new course will be similar
in purpose anti method to the Aldred lectures, although only four addresses will be given. The lectures
are designed principally to supplement the engineering course for
undergraduate students.
The addresses, which will be held
at 4.15 o'clock in the C. E. Hall,
are as follows:
March 8—"Construction of the
Catskill water supply for the City
of New York," by J. Waldo Smith,

chief engineer of the Board of Water Supply, New York City.
March 15-,—"Some Results of the
War on Engineering Research," by
C. E. Skinner, manager of the research department of the Westinghouse Electric Company, East Pittsburgh, Pa.
March 22—"Engineering Problems Involving Atmospheric Pressure," by W. H. Carrier, president
of the Carrier Engineering Corporation, Newark, N. J.
March 29 — "Magnesium, Its
Manufacture and Use," by 1.V. G.
Harvey, vice-president and superintendent of the American Magnesium Corporation, Niagara Falls,
N.Y.

BOB SKINNER ELECTED VICEPRESIDENT OF FRESHMAN
CLASS

The first meeting of the Freshman Class was held Tuesday, at
12:30, in the auditorium of the
Civil Engineering Building. After
calling the meeting to order, President Page O'Connor announced
that plans for the banquet were being arranged. After this a vote was
taken to see how many of the members of the class desired pins, but,
as there were so very many who
didn't want them, it was decided
"to let the matter slide until next
year." Treasurer "Bill" Norris
then announced that a plan had
b(:.en devised for collecting the dues
"Toots" Darley, of the Engineering School, and Gedige Hess, of
the Academic Department, are to
act as his assistants and are to keep
after the Freshmen until the dues
are paid.
President O'Connor took the
chair again and announced that
new officers would have to be elected to take the places of Spinney,
the vice-president, and Westerman,
the sergeant-at-arms, who had been
dropped from the University. Magill, Asendorf, "Bob" Skinner and
"Ed" Panneti were nominated for
vice-president. Post, Young and
Rome were nominated. to fill the position of "bouncer." Skinner was
elected vice-president. Post was
elected to the other office.

THE GAYEST EVER HELD
AT HOPKINS
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Decorations Overshadow Anything of
the Kind Ever Attempted. Spirit
of Jazz Unconfined.

Surrounded by the most futuristic, impressionistic, cubistic, tapestries which ever adorned an otherwise solemn hall, the Class of
1922 unlimbered their studently
limbs and gave themselves over to
joy unconfined and swayed themselves to thewierd strains of Seidenham's sorrow-killing orchestra of
seven pieces.
With all thoughts of unhappy
exams behind them and caring little for the future, seventy-five
couples threw their whole energies
into the delightful pastime sponsored by the god Terpsichore; caring little for the harmful news-articles daily published by minds long
since exhausted of other moneygetting material.
With the "King and Queen of
Jazz" beaming upon their disciples,
the dance went on from 9:30 P. M.
until nearly 2 A. M., 'Wednesday
morning.
The decorations were by far the
most impressive ever used at such
an affair. The personal ones Dean
Latane, Drs. Wood, French and
Mitchell rivalled those of jazzier
subjects, such as the "Cave-man's
Petting Party," "The Leg of Nations," "Mrs. Salome," the "First
Shimmy," etc.
The patrons and patronesses
were: Dr. Frank J. Goodnow, Dean
and Mrs. John B. Whitehead, Professor and Mrs. Knight Dunlap,
Mr. and Mrs. Robertson Griswold,
Dr. and Mrs. Ronald T. Abercrombie, Professor and Mrs. J. H. Gregory, Dr. and Mrs. Luther M. Parsons, Dr. and Mrs. Ray Van Orman and Mrs. Christopher Johnson.

ADVERTISE HOPKINS!

Editor of NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir: In order to help our
university by advertising it and
keeping its name before the public,
locally at least, I suggest that every
motor vehicle operated by any person connected in any capacity with
the university carry a suitable and
inexpensive Hopkins banner, pennant or emblem.
The difficulty of carrying out
such an idea as this is that someone must start it and put it into the
form of a custom by making it
popular. With this in mind, our
Motorcycle Club is ready to take
the lead and start the practice of
carrying a Hopkins banner, pennant or emblem on its machines.
Respectfully yours,
EDWARD F. BUCHNER, JR.
